The Annotated Civilisation:  II. Architecture

July 8, 2020

Periods/Styles

A.  CLASSICAL (Roman)

B.  EARLY MEDIEVAL : Byzantine—Celtic—Merovingian—Carolingian

C.  ROMANESQUE : Cluniac—Cistercian—Norman—Italian

D.  GOTHIC & its Revivial

E.  RENAISSANCE : Early—High—Late

F.  BAROQUE : French—Italian—German—English

G.  NEOCLASSICAL : French—English—American

H.  CIVIL & MILITARY : German/Austrian—Italian—French—English—Netherlandish

I.  URBAN & LANDSCAPE : Italian—French—English—Scottish—American

J.  REVIVAL, INDUSTRIAL, & MODERN

A.  Classical Roman

Tempio dei Dioscuri (Temple of Castor and Pollux), Regio VIII Forum Romanum, Roma *
  (495 BC) [1,5]

Maison Carrée, Nîmes
  (c. 2–4/7) [1]

Pont du Gard, Nîmes *
  (1C) [1]

Fontana della Pigna, Vaticano *
  (1C) [5]

Arc de Triomphe d’Orange *
  (c. 20–25) [1]

Colosseum, or Flavian Amphitheatre, Regio III Isis et Serapis, Roma *
  (70–80) [5]

Pantheon, Regio IX Circus Flaminius, Roma *
  (113–125) [5]

Grandi Terme, Villa Adriana, Tivoli *
  (2C) [5]  📖

Arco di Settimio Severo (Arch of Septimius Severus), Regio VIII Forum Romanum, Roma *
  (203) [5]

Terme di Caracalla, Regio XII Piscina Publica, Roma *
  (212–217) [5]

  (526–547) [1]

  (532–537) [1]

  (6C–8C) [1,13]

  (634–8C) [1]

b.3  Merovingian

  (c. 360/5C–6C) [1]

b.4  Carolingian

  (792–805) by Eudes de Metz [1]

  (1173–1372) by Bonanno Pisano [3]

  (1228–1253) by Elia da Cortona [2,3,13]

  (1238–1310) [4]

  (1268) [4]

  (1303–1305) [3]

  (1248–1880) [1]

  (1278) [4]

  (1296–1436), Arnolfo di Cambio and Filippo Brunelleschi [4,5]

  (1370–1520) [8,9]

E.  Renaissance

e.1  Early Renaissance

Sagrestia Vecchia, nella basilica di San Lorenzo, Firenze *
  (1419–1428) by Filippo Brunelleschi [4]

Biblioteca di San Marco, Firenze *
  (1437) by Michelozzo di Bartolomeo  [4]

Cappella Pazzi, Firenze *
  (1441–1478) by Filippo Brunelleschi [4]

Palazzo Ducale, Urbino *
  (1454) by Luciano Laurana, Francesco di Giorgio Martini, and Maso di Bartolomeo [4]

Basilica di Santa Maria delle Carceri, Prato
  (1486–1495) by Giuliano da Sangallo [4]

Palazzo Strozzi, Firenze *
  (1489–1662) by Benedetto da Maiano [4]

e.2  High Renaissance

Basilica di San Pietro, Vaticano *
  (1506–1626) by Bernardo Rossellino, Giuliano da Sangallo, Bramante, Raffaello Sanzio, Giovanni Giocondo, Antonio da Sangallo il Giovane, Baldassarre Peruzzi, Michelangelo Buonarroti, Domenico Fontana, Giacomo Della Porta, Jacopo Barozzi da Vignola, Pirro Ligorio, Carlo Maderno, and Gian Lorenzo Bernini [1,5]

Palazzo Apostolico, Vaticano *
  (1589) by Bramante, Michelangelo, Raphael, Antonio da Sangallo il Giovane, Carlo Maderno, Gian Lorenzo Bernini  [5,13]

e.3  Late Renaissance

Casina di Pio IV (Villa Pia), Vaticano *
  (1558) by Pirro Ligorio [5]

F.  Baroque

f.1  French Baroque

Chapelle Sainte Ursule de la Sorbonne, Paris
  (1635–1642) by Jacques Lemercier [12]

Château de Versailles *
  i.  Château neuf (1669–1672) by Louis Le Vau [10]
  ii.  Ailes des Ministres (1671–1679) by Jules Hardouin-Mansart [10]
  iii.  Galerie des Glaces (1678–1684) by Jules Hardouin-Mansart and Charles Le Brun [10]
  iv.  Chapelle royale de Versailles (1678–1710) by Jules Hardouin-Mansart and Robert de Cotte [10]
  v.  Aile Gabriel (1772–1985) by Ange-Jacques Gabriel [10]

Hôtel des Invalides, Paris *
  (1670–1679) by Libéral Bruant and Jules Hardouin-Mansart [1,12,13]

f.2  Italian Baroque

Chiesa di Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza, Roma *
  (1642–1660) by Francesco Borromini [9]

Chiesa di Sant’Agnese in Agone, Roma *
  (1652–1657) by Carlo Rainaldi and Francesco Borromini [5,9]

f.3  German Baroque & Rococo

Schloss Nymphenburg, Neuhausen-Nymphenburg (München)
  (1664–1719) by Agostino Barelli, Enrico Zucalli, Giovanni Antonio Viscardi, Joseph Effner, etc. [9]

Kloster Ottobeuren
  (1711-1725) [9]

Würzburger Residenz, Würzburg *
  (1720–1780) by Balthasar Neumann and Giambattista Tiepolo [9]

Amalienburg, Neuhausen-Nymphenburg (München)
  (1734–1739) by Johann Baptist Zimmermann and Joachim Dietrich [9]

Basilika Vierzehnheiligen, Bad Staffelstein
  (1743-72) by Balthasar Neumann [9]

Wallfahrtskirche zum Gegeißelten Heiland auf der Wies (Wieskirche), Steingaden *
  (1745–1754) [9]

f.4  English Baroque

St Mary-le-Bow, London
  (1671–1680) by Christopher Wren [8]

St Bride’s Church, London
  (1672–1675) by Christopher Wren [8]

St Paul’s Cathedral, London
  (1675–1710) by Christopher Wren [1,8]

St Andrew Holborn, London
  (1686) by Christopher Wren [8]

Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich *
  (1696–1712) by Christopher Wren [8,13]

Blenheim Palace, Woodstock *
  (1705–1722) by John Vanbrugh [10]

#contents

G.  Neoclassical

g.1  French Neoclassical

Palais du Louvre, Paris *
  i.  Pavillon de Marsan (1664–1666 & 1806–1811) by Louis Le Vau, Charles Percier, and Pierre Fontaine [1]
  ii.  Colonnade du Louvre (1667–1670) by Claude Perrault, Louis Le Vau, and Charles Le Brun [9]
  iii.  Les Guichets du Louvre (1861–1870) by Hector-Martin Lefuel [9]

Comédie-Française ou Théâtre-Français, Paris
  (1680) by Victor Louis [10]

Arc de Triomphe de l’Etoile, Paris
  (1806–1836) by Jean-François Chalgrin [1,12]

g.2  English Neo-Palladian

Chiswick House, London
  (1726–1729) by Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington [10]

g.3  American Neoclassical

Monticello, Charlottesville *
  (1769–1826) by Thomas Jefferson [10,13]

United States Capitol, Washington, D.C.
  (1793–1962) by William Thornton [10]

The Rotunda, University of Virginia, Charlottesville *
  (1822–1826) by Thomas Jefferson and Stanford White [10]

United States Supreme Court Building, Washington, D.C.
  (1932–1935) by Cass Gilbert and Cass Gilbert Jr. [10]

Thomas Jefferson Memorial, Washington, D.C.
  (1939–1947) by John Russell Pope and Eggers & Higgins [10]

  (1330) [4]
